conversation.content: [exhausted] Three lines. That's all it was—three lines in tomorrow's scene and I couldn't sleep last night. My agent called it my "breakthrough moment" and I just... I don't know, I kept thinking about all those years as background. You know what's funny? [pause] Nobody ever looked at me then. I could just... exist. Be part of the world without being, um, without being seen, if that makes sense. [nostalgic] God, remember that courthouse scene I did last year? Two hundred extras, and I just sat there reading an actual book between takes. [laugh] Nobody cared! It was perfect. But now they're doing close-ups and the director keeps saying "give me more with your eyes" and I'm like—honestly? I don't want to give you anything. [quietly] I think I liked being furniture. [pause] Is that weird? Everyone's so excited for me, especially my mom, she's already telling people I'm "an actress now" and I can't exactly say, er... actually, I miss being invisible. [sigh] Tomorrow they want me to cry on cue. Real tears. And all I keep thinking is how nice it was when I could just walk through frame holding a coffee cup and nobody expected me to feel anything. [trailing off] Maybe I'm just scared, I don't know...

subject: Your background character film work finally leading to speaking roles just as you discover you prefer being invisible
